headline: NZ Parliament Advances Major Water Reform, UAE CEPA Trade Pact, and Online Gambling Regulation in Day of Debates
summary: Parliament spent the day advancing several high-profile policy initiatives, including the Local Government (Water Services) Bill in a robust second-reading, sweeping reform of resource management rules, and the UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement legislation. Debates exposed tensions over cost, environmental safeguards, and human rights, as ministers defended ambitious reforms and opposition voices warned of higher rates and weaker protections. The day culminated with progress on gambling regulation and employment reform as well as routine committee work on legal services funding.

topicSummaries.topic: Water Services Reform Passes Second Reading After 367 Amendments
topicSummaries.content: The Local Government (Water Services) Bill moved to the next stage as Parliament backed the 'Water Done Well' reforms, aimed at delivering enduring, publicly owned water services through new water organisations and updated governance. The Finance and Expenditure Committee produced 367 amendments, strengthening accountability, and setting two new statutory objectives to underpin housing growth and efficient water infrastructure. While supporters praised the plan to secure reliable drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater systems, critics warned of rate pressures and the risk of central intervention. The bill now proceeds to the committee of the whole House for detailed consideration.

keyExchanges.speaker: Simon Watts (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This Government is getting councils back to basics, focusing on the core services Kiwis rely on.

keyExchanges.speaker: Simon Watts (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This is the third and final piece of legislation for implementing Local Water Done Well, the Government's plan to address water services challenges.

topicSummaries.topic: Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Bill Second Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Bill formed part of a three-phase reform of the RMA, with a focus on fast-tracking infrastructure and housing growth, and clarifying governance around farming and energy projects. Highlights include redefining long-lived infrastructure to support electricity and transport, and enabling Auckland’s plan-change flexibility to preserve housing capacity after recent floods. Debates covered hydrology safeguards, the MDRS, and concerns about potential weakening of environmental protections, with amendments to section 70 and freshwater farm-plans oversight under discussion. The bill was advanced to the committee of the whole House for further scrutiny.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (National)
keyExchanges.quote: We are in this three-phase programme to reform the Resource Management Act (RMA). We've done phase one and we're in the middle of phase two.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon TRACEY MCLLELLAN (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Section 70 discharge... replace the term 'Before' with the phrase 'Except as provided in subsection (3), before'.

topicSummaries.topic: United Arab Emirates CEPA Legislation Amendment Bill Second Reading
topicSummaries.content: The United Arab Emirates Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement Legislation Amendment Bill progressed, aiming to implement the UAE–NZ CEPA by aligning domestic law with the agreement and enabling tariff elimination for most exports. Supporters stressed the deal’s economic value and rapid negotiation, while critics highlighted human rights concerns, migrant-worker protections, and the need to uphold Te Tiriti. The debate underscored balancing trade diversification and principled diplomacy, with the bill advancing to a full legislative vote.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon PHIL TWYFORD (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The United Arab Emirates are one of our top 20 trading partners, and this agreement will, within three years, move 99 percent of our exports to duty-free status and eliminate tariffs.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon PHIL TWYFORD (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The United Arab Emirates' human rights fall well short in areas of labour rights, the rights of migrant workers, freedom of expression, and freedom of assembly.

topicSummaries.topic: Online Casino Gambling Bill First Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Online Casino Gambling Bill was introduced and given a first reading, proposing a regulated market with up to 15 licensed operators, a 1.24% profits levy for problem gambling support, GST, and a 12% offshore gambling duty. The bill emphasizes age verification, exclusion of problem gamblers, and regulatory enforcement by the Department of Internal Affairs, with penalties up to $5 million for breaches. The debate featured strong partisan views, with Green Party MPs warning about harms and Māori communities' vulnerability, while National and NZ First urged careful regulation and rapid progression to select committee.

keyExchanges.speaker: Lemauga Lydia Sosene (Labour—Māngere)
keyExchanges.quote: I oppose this bill. I am concerned that this bill opens up doors to offshore gambling casinos without having a strong plan for harm reduction.

keyExchanges.speaker: Lemauga Lydia Sosene (Labour—Māngere)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill will bring in short-term profits and convenience, and it will have a long-term negative effect.

topicSummaries.topic: Employment Relations Amendment Bill First Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Employment Relations Amendment Bill was introduced with major reforms aimed at boosting labour-market flexibility, reducing compliance costs, and rebalancing the personal grievance framework. Key provisions include a gateway test to clarify contractor status, an income threshold for unjustified dismissal, expansion of 90-day trials, and removal of the 30-day rule to empower more bespoke employment terms. The bill drew strong opposition from Labour and Green MPs, who argued it undermined workers’ protections, while National and NZ First contended it would boost growth and productivity. The first-reading vote advanced the bill to the Education and Workforce Committee for scrutiny.

keyExchanges.speaker: Brooke Van Velden (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill enhances labour market flexibility, reduces compliance costs, and re-tilt the personal grievance system to better balance employer and employee interests.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Ginny Andersen (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The 30-day rule makes it difficult for employers and employees to agree bespoke terms and conditions, such as a 90-day trial for new employees.

conclusion: Today highlighted Parliament’s push to advance transformative reforms across water governance, environmental planning, trade, and employment, even as critics warned of higher costs and weakened protections; the bills now move into committee scrutiny with potential for further amendments and refinements.
